"""
All =
the talk in the media about the treatment of Iraqi prisoners and the

f Iraqi women has me remembering my days in the U.S. Marine Corps.

e things in particular struck me. Number one, the idea that the

ry is a "value-based organization". And the second thing

ple who did what has been reported and photographed to the Iraqi

majority of the military.

 stuck out in my mind

relates directly to the above topics. In all of =
our training, be it Boot
Camp,
Infantry School, or on-going regular unit tr=
aining, we were taught two

 to be extremely aggressive on

nprecedented in "civil"

ay the level expected from

mart while we were being
aggressive. This latter teaching involved overcomi=
ng our own normal
fears and
instinctive reactions so that we could more eff=
iciently channel our
aggresion
towards killing the enemy while sustaining m=
inimal casualties ourselves.
These
two things combined make a truly deadly =
combination, even without
"modern"
weapons.

Sometime during our initial tr=
aining, we were schooled in how to behave
generally. We were told morals. W=
e were told how to be "honorable" and
"just". But what stuck out was that I=
 could see that what we were being
told
about these things did not fit well=
 at all with the aggression and the
killing
smarts that we were being taugh=
t elsewhere in our training. And probably
you
can guess where the emphasis =
lay. On one hand we should be deadly and
savage
killing machines, and on th=
e other hand we should be polite, honorable,
and
reserved. Clearly these tw=
o worlds do not match. And the one that was
tied to
survival and "winning" =
would surely be the one that would "win out" over
the
other.

This was part=
icularly clear to me when I spent about a year on a USMC
base in
Okinawa, J=
apan. You've probably all heard about the problems they've had
with
rapes a=
nd assaults on Japanese Nationals in Okinawa from U.S.
servicemen. I
watche=
d myself and the other men in my unit as we trained hard on how to
best

l the enemy, and then in the evenings we went out into town and were
expect=
ed to behave like civil gentleman and treat others as human
beings. Often
I=
 was shocked at the irony of the situation. The ONLY thing that

from being MORE aggressive in town was the fact that the Japanese Police
w=
ere
as tough as we were and they had weapons and were allowed by law to use=

any
amount of force they wanted to.

In Boot Camp, we were subjected to a =
great many humiliating experiences,

se things were a part of the

s and also included things

sleep deprivation and severe stress. Please=
 note, THESE THINGS WERE DONE

RECRUITS! It is only natural that some of =

those
same techniques on others, including on=
 other Marines. To say that

the military who do these things to =
others only represents a small
number of
deviants is hogwash. We were all T=
AUGHT these things by having them done
to us!

And not only were we taught =
to do these kinds of things, in many cases

encouraged, sometimes ev=
en by tradition. For instance, when an enlisted

gained rank, all other =
enlisted men of the same rank or higher in the

the newly promoted man in a certain way. For E-3 and

ched in each shoulder. I became a Lance Corporal (E-3)

a unit of about forty enlisted men with all but about a half

E- 3 or above. More than thirty Marines literally lined up in a

in the shoulder at the same time, one on each side. I have pictures of

bruises that literally wrapped around the top of my arms 360 degrees!

most
men considered these bruises marks of honor! I couldn't move my arms f=
or

week. When a Marine was promoted to Corporal (E-4), then not only was
=
the

ormal

nths

ular unit, there was a group of Marines in the unit

ppen to me for obvious reasons. But there wasn't much we could do

 Our leaders didn't care and considered it just "play" among the

e tip of

arine for four

CH OTHER!

nts" among a few

 man

No=
w taking this all into account, just imagine for a minute what would

rs

n were
